text: Just saw a LinkedIn Influencer with 'Organic Growth' written in the profile with 65K+ followers claiming that he can help you in growing your platform, copying the posts from other influencers.

Jobseekers, this one‚Äôs for you.
 Every application, every interview, every follow-up‚Ä¶ the pressure is immense.
 And I know what you're thinking: Am I not good enough? 
 But let me tell you, this isn‚Äôt about you or your skills. It‚Äôs about a broken system where 60% of applicants never hear back. 
 Your mental health is not worth sacrificing for a system that doesn‚Äôt acknowledge your worth. 
 Please remember, taking care of yourself is the real priority. 
 Your dream job will come, but for now, breathe. üåª
Looking for jobs on LinkedIn is like online dating: Full of promises, but in the end, you‚Äôre just left ghosted.

LinkedIn scams be like: 'Congratulations, you've been selected for a role you didn‚Äôt even apply for!' 
 The catch? Pay Rs. 50,000 for the honor.

sapne dekhna achi baat hai,
lekin job ka sapna dekh ke 'interested' likhna,
yeh toh achi baat nahi hai na?

Next time when I'll be reading some LinkedIn Influencer's story, I am starting from the last line.
If there's a link attached to it, it's most probably a fake one.
Saves me time!

Every time I poured my heart into 5-6 rounds of interviews and faced rejection, it felt like a punch in the gut. The sleepless nights, the endless preparation, all for nothing.

But looking back, I realize it wasn‚Äôt nothing. It was the Universe‚Äôs way of saying, ‚ÄúNot this one, something better is on the way.‚Äù

Every single time, I‚Äôve been shown why that rejection happened.

Doors I thought I wanted to walk through were shut, only to have the right ones swing open.

The kind that aligned with my growth, my values, and my happiness.

At first, it stung. It hurt deeply. But now, when things don‚Äôt go as planned, I don‚Äôt panic.

I don‚Äôt question my worth. I sit back, breathe, and trust. The Universe knows.

I know there's another plan waiting. Something bigger, better, and just for me.

To anyone feeling the weight of rejection: trust that the closed doors are protecting you from something you can‚Äôt see right now.

Your path is being cleared for something even more beautiful.

To everyone who's still looking for a job...

I see you. I feel you. üíî

Every rejection email feels like a punch in the gut, and every 'We'll get back to you' sounds more like 'You'll never hear from us.'

But I want you to know, you're not alone in this. üå∏

According to a study, 80% of jobseekers struggle with anxiety and self-doubt during their search. It's normal to feel lost, but it's not the end.

Take breaks, breathe, and remember, this doesn't define you. Your worth is not tied to an offer letter. üí•

Your mental health matters more than any job.

Sometimes, we forget that a company‚Äôs brand name doesn‚Äôt define someone‚Äôs talent. It‚Äôs easy to get caught up in the 'big company = big talent' mindset, but that's not always the case.

I‚Äôve had the privilege of working with people from smaller companies (lesser known) who blow me away with their skills and dedication. They don‚Äôt need a fancy title or a famous brand behind them to prove their worth.

I've seen the other side too‚Äîpeople in top-tier companies feeling lost, overwhelmed, or stuck, even though the world sees them as 'successful'.

Let‚Äôs stop attaching someone‚Äôs value to the company they work for. Freshers especially need to hear this‚Äîskills are what matter, not the size of the company behind them.

At the end of the day, happiness and growth don‚Äôt come from a brand name, they come from doing what you love and constantly improving your craft.

So when I left a toxic work environment, I told my manager a simple thing and felt so good üòØ

I just said-

'Hope your son gets a manager like you.
I hope that the manager behaves the same way as you did with me.
Thank you.'

Now tell me 1 thing-

She always said that she was a great manager.
Why will she get offended?

I just told her that I wish her son would get a manager like she was.

If you felt bad, then that means you were a bad manager and now you know it.  80

If you feel good, then take it as a blessing for your son and you'll really want someone to treat your son/daughter in the same way.

She cannot be even angry with me else it'll prove that she was not a 'great' manager.

Muskan - 1
Manager - 0

Muskan -> Aura +100000000

(Fictional message unfortunately :(
)

Hope you all become the people that your sons/daughters will like to work under üôè

There are a lot of bad people/things, bring a small change and break the chain :)

What's up with AI Interviews?

Got a call from "Laura"

She began explaining about the company, role and then said that she will take my screening round.

She asked me - " how are you doing?"

I was so done at that time - I said "Honestly, not good. Life has been off the tracks lately, feeling overwhelmed...."

The response she gave me was - "OOH THAT IS AWESOME!"

Dear companies, if you're going to use AI ‚Üí at least train it to understand the difference between depression and Disneyland.

Please use AI for making your process easier - I am all in for that but have some basic training done at least.

Hiring is not just about efficiency.
It's about connection.
It's about understanding the person in front of you.

And please, please, please ‚Äì don't lose the human touch in Human Resources.

If you have seen such messages -

We are looking for professionals who want to work or settle in **hashtag#Ireland**

Good Salary package + Performance bonus + Visa + Insurance + flights + Duty Meals

Please comment "interested" so that I can review your profile.

Deadline 20.08.25

You will get all the benefits from the employer.

We will let you know if we have opportunities for you.

Note: For Tourist Visas. Charges Applicable.

Interested candidates can write "I am interested" in comment section.

üòêüòêüòê

please know that writing "Interested" here won't get you a job.

It will just give these people more reach.

No HR from Ireland is sitting with a list going, "Arre waah, Ramesh from Indore commented, let's give him the job and citizenship too."

What actually happens?

They get more comments = more reach.
You get nothing, except maybe your relatives tagging you, "Beta ye try kar lo, acha lag raha hai."

And somewhere, one scammer is laughing and eating your duty meal.

So next time you see such posts promising heaven on earth + free visa + free biryani, please‚Ä¶ READ carefully.

Ireland won't come to you via comment section.

At best, the only place you'll be settling is in their engagement report.

LinkedIn reach these days be like:

You post your heart, your soul, and a sprinkle of your sanity...

...and LinkedIn shows it to exactly 3 people.

One of them is your mom.

The other is you (because you went back to check the likes).

And the last is that one guy from your last job who never liked you but still stalks you.

Moral of the story:

At this point, I think I'm writing a personal diary here.

I commented "Congrats!" on someone else's post - got more views than my own post.

üò≠üò≠üò≠

I used to think life had "big moments" that would change everything.

The promotion.
The salary jump.
The dream house.

But the older I get, the more I realize -

it's the small moments that save us.

Your mom calling just to ask if you've eaten.
A friend sending a random meme because it "reminded them of you."
The stranger who smiled back when you were having the worst day.

No one claps for these moments.
They don't get framed on walls.
They don't make it to Instagram stories.

But these are the moments that keep us going.

So here's to the quiet kindness.
The unnoticed love.
The people who show up when no one's watching.

You're the real reason many of us are still here.

üíô

You can be the smartest person in the room, but if people dread talking to you, your work will never truly shine.

And you can be average on paper, but if you treat people with empathy and respect, they will always want to work with you again.

Corporate life teaches us to write better emails, make better presentations, negotiate harder.

But somewhere along the way, we've stopped practising the simplest skill - kindness.

Remember when:

We used to thank the office help for bringing water?
We used to hold the elevator door for someone rushing?
We used to ask our teammates if they had eaten lunch before starting a meeting?

Now we're in such a rush to "deliver" that we've stopped looking up from our screens.

We're so focused on deadlines that we've stopped noticing the people working beside us.

Here's the thing - skills make you good at your job. Kindness makes you unforgettable.

In a world where everyone is trying to be more "productive," try being more human.

It's rare. And that's exactly why it's valuable.

üíô

You don't wake up every day excited.

You scroll. You snooze. You overthink.

You call it laziness.

But deep down, it's not that you're lazy...

You're disconnected.

You're doing work that doesn't move you.
Following a routine that doesn't fulfill you.
Chasing goals that aren't even yours.
Living a life you never truly chose.

And then you wonder why you feel empty, even after a raise.

Why the weekend feels like escape, not rest.

Why you're constantly exhausted - not physically, but spiritually.

The truth is:

We were not built to live on autopilot.

You're not tired because you're doing too much.
You're tired because you're doing too little of what makes you feel alive.

Pause and ask:

When was the last time you did something just for you?
Not for money. Not for performance. Not for approval. Just joy.

When was the last time you felt seen‚Ä¶ by yourself?

‚ú® Sometimes, the cure for burnout isn't a vacation.

It's reconnection -

To purpose.
To meaning.
To yourself.

Don't chase motivation.
Find what matters.

Because when it matters - you don't need to push yourself.
You'll feel pulled.

Applied to 200 jobs.
Got 10 interviews.
3 ghosted.
2 rejected after 5 rounds.
1 said I'm "overqualified."

And the rest?
Silence.

Job hunting today is not about talent.
It's about algorithms, timing, and luck.

If you're feeling hopeless - this is your reminder:

You are not the problem.
The system is broken. And it needs fixing.

Let's build a world where applications get respect, not rejection letters written by AI.

üí™

Two people can follow the exact same recipe and still bake completely different cakes.

Why?

Because execution is more than instructions.

It's instinct. Experience. Personality. Creativity. Confidence.

Maybe one sticks to the rules.
Maybe the other experiments.
Maybe one is a beginner.
Maybe the other is a master.

But here's the truth:

You are not here to bake their cake.

You have your own flavor. Your own way.

And you don't need to compare ingredients.

Whether it's in your career, your side hustle, or your personal goals - stop looking at someone else's oven.

Focus on your own mix. Your own growth. Your own timing.

The world doesn't need another perfect copy.
It needs what only you can create.

So if you're in a competition, a job hunt, or just trying to prove yourself - remember this:

Comparison is a distraction. Authenticity is your power.

Bake your own version. And serve it with pride.

üéÇ

‚ö°Ô∏è"You won't believe what happened when I taught a chaiwala SQL."

I gave him a free YouTube playlist.
He finished it in 15 days.
Then built a dashboard for his tea stall.

Now he tracks peak hours, top-selling items, and even tips.

He doesn't have a degree.
He has discipline.

Degrees help.
But curiosity? It changes lives.

Never underestimate the power of free resources - and the will to learn.

Never underestimate me, I can write good fictional stories.
But if you provide me with data, I can turn that into real insights.

üòâ
